doc.title: Upgrade to Buy: Monetization momentum with strong underlying utility growth
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Upgrade to Buy Monetization momentum with strong underlying utility growthUpgrade to Buy Monetization momentum with stro_2025-08-29

passages.text: Rating Change: BUY | PO: 84.00 USD | Price: 78.21 USD

We upgrade Southwest Gas Holdings (Swx) to Buy from Neutral. This upgrade reflects Swx's improving risk/reward profile as it sells its interest in Centuri Holdings (CTRI) and recycles capital into its core utility. This transition will result in higher earnings and rate base growth, and an improved valuation. Reflective of this, we are adjusting our EPS sets and raising our price objective to \(84\) (from \(\) 76\(prior).

On 8/7, Swx sold down \(- 5350mm\) of its CTRl interest taking its pro- forma ownership to \(- 31\%\) . After the sale, Swx announced that it will account for its remaining interest using equity method accounting. We believe there is now a clear path to completely exit the CTRl interest, thus removing a key investor overhang that has pressured valuation.

SWx currently trades at a \(- 1\%\) discount to gas LDC peer's vs an average \(3\%\) premium historically. This discount is unwarranted given 1) de- risked balance sheet through CTRl sell down, 2) above average EPS CAGR of \(- 12\%\) , 3) pending Q3 update on the Great Basin expansion project, and 4) constructive regulatory outlook. We are updating our 25/26/27 EPS estimates to \(\) 3.68/\(\) 4.01/\(\) 4.60\(from\) \ \(3.68 /\) 4.14 / \(\) 4.56\(prior.

We increase our PO to \(\) 84\(from\) \ \(76\) prior after updating the 2027E peer group gas LDC P/E multiple. We now take out CTRl's 2027 equity value as we assume a full exit by 2025 year- end. We increase the applied premium on Arizona to \(10\%\) from \(0\%\) prior due to the improving regulatory landscape and increase the applied premium on Great Basin to \(15\%\) from \(0\%\) to capture the large investment opportunity and strong FERC- regulated ROE of \(11.95\%\) . We now see \(11\%\) total return in our SOTP analysis. With Swx trading at a discount to historical levels, we see the stock as undervalued compared to gas LDC peers when considering the growth opportunity and view the current valuation as an attractive entry point into the name.

Southwest Gas Corp. (SWX) is a natural gas distribution and transportation company headquartered in Las Vegas, Nevada. Its operations are divided into two segments: Natural Gas Distribution and Construction Services. Gas Distribution transports, distributes and sells natural gas to roughly 2.0mn customers in Arizona, Nevada, and California. Construction Services offers pipe construction, maintenance, and repair services to LDCs around the country

We are Buy rated on SWX given attractive risk/reward profile driven by the utility business fundamentals. SWX has an above average EPS growth CAGR of \(12\%\) driven by the Great Basin expansion project and limited equity needs to fund growth from the CTRI monetizations. With a derisked balance sheet through the CTRI sell downs and the improving AZ regulatory outlook (from the SIM and formula rates), current valuation levels present an attractive entry point.
Average Daily Volume 373,246
Source: BofA Global Research, Company filings, Bloomberg

We update our model and EPS estimates post 2Q25 earnings and the recent August 2025 CTRI sell-down. We also bake in the low end of management's forecasted incremental capex range for the Great Basin Pipeline expansion project ( \(1.2 - 1.6bn\) ) into numbers ( \(- 1.2bn\) from 2026- 2028 with a \(20\%\) , \(25\%\) and \(50\%\) annual cost cadence). With the incremental \(- 1.2bn\) of capex related to Great Basin, we now model a \(10\%\) rate base CAGR from 2025- 2029. We also assume a complete exit from CTRI by 2025 year- end (an additional \(- 500mn+\) of net proceeds).

With the proceeds from the CTRI monetization eliminating the HoldCo debt and related interest expense and the Great Basin capex upside, we forecast SWX's long- term EPS growing at \(- 11.5\%\) from 2025- 2029 (vs \(12\%\) Consensus), above the top end of management's current \(6 - 8\%\) net income guidance.

We expect \(- 7c\) of hold- co drag from 2026 onwards from remaining O&M items like executive comp, incentives, wages, etc. We expect management will provide further clarity on capex related to the Great Basin expansion on 3Q25 earnings, with a fulsome guidance update at 4Q25 earnings.

CTRI proceeds limit equity funding needs for the capex forecast. We model zero equity needs until 2028 (due to the \(- 1bn\) of net proceeds from a full CTRI monetization in 2025) and show a \(200mn\) equity need in 2028. We model an average of \(- 500mn\) of annual debt issuance from 2026- 2029, when considering both the Great Basin expansion and funds from the full CTRI monetization. Our 2025/2026/2027 EPS estimates are now \(3.68 / 4.01 / 4.60\) changed from \(3.68 / 4.14 / 4.45\) prior.
Exhibit 2:SWX EPS Dashboard Updating estimates for 2Q25, CTRI proceeds, and Great Basin

We are increasing our PO to \(84 from\) 76 prior after updating the 2027E peer group gas LDC P/E multiple to 17.3x from 15.6x prior. We now take out CTRL's 2027 equity value from our valuation given we are now assuming a full CTRI exit by 2025 year- end.

We now increase the applied premium on Arizona to \(10\%\) from \(0\%\) prior due to the improving regulatory landscape and increase the applied premium on Great Basin to \(15\%\) from \(0\%\) to capture the large investment opportunity and strong FERC- regulated ROE of \(11.95\%\) .

In Arizona, the System Integrity Mechanism (SIM) tracker (a tracker that accounts for \(- 40\%\) of Southwest Gas' Arizona dedicated infrastructure costs) and formula rate implementation likely in the next rate case by 2027, we model improving regulatory lag in AZ starting in 2027.

We now see \(11\%\) total return in our SOTP analysis. Fundamentals for the natural gas distribution business appear stronger given the large investment opportunity ( \(1.2bn-\) \(1.6nm\) ) at the FERC- regulated Great Basin pipeline and improving regulatory jurisdictions (AZ, NV), whilst the consolidated business stands to benefit from a strong cash position resulting from the full CTRI monetization, driving reduced hold- co drag.
With Swx trading at a discount to historical levels, we see the stock as undervalued compared to gas LDC peers and view the current valuation level as an attractive entry point to the name.

On August 11, 2025, SWX closed on their third monetization out of CTRI. Proceeds from the transaction will be used to pay down all remaining Hold-co debt, lowering hold-co interest expense to $0 moving forward. 2025-2026 equity needs have been eliminated and remaining proceeds garnered from future sell-downs out of CTRI will be used for capex funding and cash taxes related to the transactions.

SWX currently owns 27,362,210 shares of CTRI (-30.9% of total outstanding shares of Centuri) and as a result, no longer has a controlling financial interest in CTRI. SWX will deconsolidate CTRI's financial statements from its consolidated financial statements effective as of August 11, 2025.

We show the breakdown of what the net proceeds could be if SWX fully monetizes their position in CTRI below. Now that they have a -31% stake, they will deconsolidate CTRI's financials from SWX's consolidated financials moving forward.
SWX's net proceeds from CTRI sales
**Full Net proceeds to SWX from full CTRI exit (tax effected)**
**Source**: BofA Global Research, Company filings, Bloomberg
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
GRC: General Rate Case
FERC: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission
Gas LDC: Gas Local Distribution Company

Our S84 PO for Swx is based on a sum- of- the- parts analysis. We apply the peer gas 2027 P/E multiple (17.3x) and 'gross- up' by 5% to account for growth across the sector. We apply a 10% premium on Arizona due to the improving regulatory landscape and apply a 15% on the Great Basin business to capture the large investment opportunity and strong FERC- regulated ROE of 11.95%. We value the other two regulated businesses at an in- line multiple given the strength of the regulated business while considering inherent regulatory risk implied by active rate cases.

Upside risks to achieving the Price Objective are 1) positive regulatory outcomes, 2) ability to earn regulatory rates of return, 3) improved capital markets access, 4) rating agency actions, 5) regulatory, legislative, or judicial outcomes, 6) infrastructure services performance 7) improved construction margins.

Downside risks to achieving the Price Objective are 1) negative regulatory outcomes, 2) inability to earn regulatory rates of return, 3) poor capital markets access, 4) rating agency actions, 5) regulatory, legislative, or judicial outcomes. 6) infrastructure services performance 7) poor construction margins 8) separation transaction risk.
